School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 PR China Graphical abstract N-doped carbon-based materials have been regarded as promising alternative metal-free catalysts for the production of vinyl chloride monomer. In this work, N-doped carbon-based catalysts were synthesized via a melamine/formaldehyde/ polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) coating-pyrolysis method, and the performances of the resultant catalysts (N@CBC-FE) were investigated and compared with those of the control samples. The optimal N@CBC-FE catalyst presented the highest acetylene conversion of 75 % at 220 °C and an acetylene gas hourly space velocity of 50 h−1 in 120 h. N2 sorption, Raman spectroscopy, attenuated total Reflectance-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and temperature-programmed desorption analysis results revealed that the excellent performance of N@CBC-FE was mainly attributed to the unique nitrogen intercalation pathway generated by the polymeric network coating, which was produced by the reactions among formaldehyde, PVA and melamine. Moreover, the abundant mesopores of N@CBC-FE facilitated the transfer of the reactants and retarded the deactivation process. This work is expected to provide new insights for the preparation of N-doped activated carbon-based catalysts. Keywords Nitrogen-doping Activated carbon-based catalysts Melamine Polymeric network coating Acetylene hydrochlorination 1 Introduction Currently, in most western regions of China, the supported HgCl2/C catalyst is commonly used for the industrial hydrochlorination of acetylene to afford vinyl chloride monomer (VCM), which is an important intermediate in the synthesis of plastic polyvinyl chloride (PVC) [1]. Considering the toxicity and volatility of HgCl2 and the related human-health issues, more than 140 countries signed the Minamata Convention on Mercury, demanding the elimination of mercury pollution [2]. Thus, the development of mercury-free candidates for acetylene hydrochlorination in the coal-based PVC industry is imperative. For decades, significant fundamental researches on promising mercury-free catalysts have been conducted [3,4], including metallic catalysts (Au [3,5,6], Ru [7–12], Pd [13,14], Cu [15–17].), nonmetallic carbon (N-doped [18–23], SiC [24], g-C3N4 [25], MCN [26,27], CNT [28], graphene [29,30]) and supported ionic liquids catalysts [8,31–33]. Inexpensive, environmentally benign, and corrosion-resistant metal-free catalysts, particularly activated carbon (AC)-derived catalysts, are fitting replacements for expensive metallic catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination [34–38]. By introducing heteroatoms, such as N [18,22,27,39–41], S [42–44], and P [45–47] into the carbon framework, its catalytic performance was improved due to the electron delocalization and modulation of the electronic structure as well as the production of new defect sites [48–51]. The above advantages position heteroatom-doped carbon materials as one of the essential components of nonmetallic catalysts. Among the numerous heteroatom-doped carbon materials, N-doped carbon-based materials (NCMs) have attracted significant attention because of their available raw material sources and their satisfactory catalytic activity [52,53]. Numerous NCMs have been extensively investigated recently. Bao and coworkers synthesized N-doped ordered mesoporous carbon (N-OMC) via NH3 treatment, which afforded an acetylene conversion of 77 % after 100 h at 200 °C [18]. To improve the stability of NCM, they synthesized a SiC@N-C catalyst via in situ vapor deposition, which afforded an acetylene conversion of 80 % at 200 °C, they proposed that pyrrolic-N could increase the electron density of the support [24]. Afterwards, they deposited a N layer on the surface of SiC via polymerized dopamine, and the synthesized PDA/SiC exhibited good activity (∼78 %) and stability (350 h) under the conditions of 200 °C and 0.8 mL/g/min [54]. Wei and coworker in situ synthesized N-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) from ammonia, reporting a turnover frequency (TOF) of 2.3 × 10−3/s, and the activity of the N-CNTs was correlated with the amount of quaternary N [28]. Dai and coworkers prepared a g-C3N4/AC catalyst from cyanamide, which presented an acetylene conversion of 75 % under the conditions of 180 °C and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 50 h-1, they suggested that the pyridinic-N improved the adsorption of hydrogen chloride (HCl) onto the catalysts [25]. Meanwhile, they utilized the polyaniline (PANI) as the precursor to synthesize the PANI-AC (5/1)900 catalyst, which afforded a conversion of 76 % under the condition of 180 °C and 36 h-1 GHSV(C2H2) [40]. In our previous work, Li and her coworkers synthesized N-doped carbon materials derived from ZIF8 and melamine. The synthesized optimal Z4M1 afforded an acetylene conversion of 60 % at 180 °C and 36 h-1, suggesting pyrrolic-N as the active site [20,23]. Song and coworkers also reported a C-NH3 catalyst derived from ZIF-8, which afforded a 92 % acetylene conversion during a 200 h test at 220 °C and 30 h-1 GHSV [22]. As listed in Table S1, all the above researches illustrate that the N species indeed function positively during the reaction. However, the elucidation of the catalytic roles of different N species is still a challenge. Podyacheva and Ismagilov summarized that N dopants exert anchoring effects, accelerate the electron transfers and alter the acid base properties [55,56]. In addition, Li and coworkers synthesized N-doped mesoporous carbons (N-OMC-O2.0) by incorporating the SBA-15 template and urea precursor, and the amount of doped N in the carbon matrix could be up to 3.6 wt.% [21]. Subsequently, they prepared another N-OMC from wheat flour/gluten, and the NCM performed excellently (＞ 85 % conversion in 30 h) at 200 °C, 30 h-1 GHSV, they proposed that the predominant quaternary N species would be the active sites [27]. Therefore, the hierarchical pore structure, including both the micro- and mesopores in the supports could also enhance catalytic performance [18,21,23]. Although the NCMs have been explored to modify the physicochemical properties of materials, accompanied by the manifestation of their catalytic activities, most works focus on doping with different N-containing precursors or different doping strategies, and all these factors influence the final N content, ratio of different N species, structural defect and surface modification or functionalization [22]. Recently, Hashimoto and coworkers adopted formaldehyde to dissolve melamine to obtain a N-rich NCM, which showed excellent activity for the oxygen evolution reaction [57]. Thereafter, Li and coworkers added polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) into the melamine/formaldehyde (MF) resin to modulate the construction of the MF resin sphere, obtaining a hollow HMCS/GN, which exhibited excellent electrochemical performance [58]. Conversely, previous literature indicated that the formation of the MF resin consisted of two steps: in the methylolation reaction, melamine reacted with formaldehyde to produce a sequence of distinct methylol melamine. Thereafter, in the condensation step, different various oligomers can be generated containing methylene and methylene ether bridges [59,60]. We are enlightened to adopt the intriguing N-rich structure of methylol melamine to prepare N-doped carbon catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. In this study, as shown in Scheme 1 , we prepared N-doped AC samples using a melamine/formaldehyde/PVA (MFP) coating-pyrolysis method, and assessed their activities for acetylene hydrochlorination. N2 sorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) analysis results revealed that through the MFP coating-pyrolysis method major N species of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N were introduced into the prepared catalyst, which led to the high catalytic activity with an acetylene conversion up to 75 % under the conditions of 220 °C and 50 h−1 GHSV(C2H2) in 120 h. These results would provide guidance on the design of metal-free catalysts for the more efficient production of VCM from acetylene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Commercial coal-based activated carbon (CBC) was purchased from Ningxia Huahui Activated Carbon Co., Ltd.). Melamine, ethanol (EL, purity ＞ 99.9 %), glycol (GL, purity ＞ 99.9 %) and formaldehyde solution (FE, 37 wt.%), and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, n = 1750) were purchased from CheMart (Tianjin) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. All the other materials and chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of N-doped samples Three kinds of modified samples were synthesized using different solvents, and they were denoted as N@CBC-FE, N@CBC-EL and N@CBC-GL. The N@CBC-FE sample was prepared using a modified procedure, based on the synthesis method of the MF/PVA composite [61]. Firstly, a certain amount of PVA (0.12 g) was dissolved and sealed in 8.50 mL of formaldehyde solution at 90 °C until complete dissolution. Secondly, melamine (2.50 g) was transferred into the above solution and stirred at 90 °C to form a clear solution. Thereafter, CBC (5.0 g) was added dropwise and stirred for 30 min until no bubbles were released. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to dry at 120 °C for 12 h, followed by calcination in a quartz tube at 700 °C for 2 h under an N2 atmosphere at a flow rate of 100 mL/min and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. After cooling to room temperature, approximately 5.44 g of the sample was obtained, which was denoted as N@CBC-FE. As a control, N-doped catalyst samples were prepared with ethanol and glycol solvents. To prepare N@CBC-EL, typically, melamine (2.50 g) was dissolved in ethanol (15.0 mL) at 25 °C with stirring for 1 h. Afterward, the CBC (5.0 g) was added into the above solution and stirred for another 1 h. The obtained mixture was sealed and aged at 60 °C for 12 h, followed by evaporation and desiccation at 150 °C for 12 h. Thereafter, the resultant was calcined under conditions similar to those for N@CBC-FE, and 5.22 g of the N@CBC-EL sample was collected. Similarly, N@CBC-GL was prepared under the same conditions except that glycol was used instead of ethanol in the above procedure, finally, we obtained ∼ 5.28 g of N@CBC-GL. The mass change of each N@CBC-x sample after doping was provided in Table S2. 2.3 Characterization The textural properties of the samples were determined by N2 sorption isothermals at −196 °C using Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ Instruments. The surface areas were obtained via the Brauner-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory, and the pore diameters of the samples were analyzed based on the isotherm desorption curves. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method and the t-plot method were adopted to analyze the mesoporous and microporous characteristics, respectively. The morphology of the samples was analyzed using Hitachi S4800 FESEM at 5 kV. The Raman spectra were collected using a NTEGRA instrument with a 632.8 nm laser, and the spectra were analyzed using the origin 8.0 software. The functional groups on the surface of NCM were identified using NICOLET-iz10 via FTIR. Before the test, the sample mixed with KBr was ground and pressed into a disk. The contents of C, N and O in the samples were measured on Element Vario MACRO Cube. XPS measurement was performed using a Thermo ESCALAB-250xi system equipped with a non-monochromatic Mg Kα1,2 excitation source. The TPD tests were conducted using Thermal AutoChem to measure the adsorption capacity of the reactants and products. The adsorption of the reactants was tested in the reactors; the procedure was as follows: the fresh sample was pre-adsorbed by the reactant gas (20 mL/min) at 180 °C for 4 h. After cooling, the sample was transferred to a U-type tube and was heated from 50 to 500 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min under a flow of 130 mL/min helium (purity, 99.9 %). NH3-TPD test was analyzed on AutoChem II 2920. The sample was put into U-type tube followed by purging with He flow for 30 min at 120 °C. After cooling, the sample was adsorbed by 10 % NH3/He (volume fraction) with a low flow rate for 2 h, then the TCD signal was recorded under a He flow and heating from 50 °C to 500 °C. In situ Pyridine-IR (Py-IR) experiment was conducted using Thermo Fisher IS50, prior to test, the samples were mixed with KBr to grind and press a tablet which was fixed in an infrared sample pool, vacuumed at 300 °C for 4 h, and then cooled to 25 °C and pyridine was adsorbed for 1 h, after removing the physically adsorbed pyridine, and the spectra was recorded. The coking of the catalysts was analyzed using a Mettler Toledo thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) SDTA851e instrument from 30 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in air atmosphere at a flow rate of 50 mL/min. The coking amount was calculated in the temperature range of 100−450 °C [20]. 2.4 Catalysts evaluation The catalysts were evaluated in a fixed bed reactor with a 10 mm inner diameter. The reactor was swept by N2 before the evaluation. The loaded catalyst (3 mL) was activated by HCl gas for 1 h, after which an acetylene flow was fed into the reactor to initiate the reaction. The internal diffusion could be prevented as the catalyst particle size equals 20–40 mesh, and the external diffusion could be prevented as the C2H2 flow rate was higher than 14 mL/min [62]. For comparison all optimization experiments were conducted under the conditions of 220 °C and the acetylene GHSV of 180 h−1. The lifetime evaluation was conducted under the conditions of 220 °C and 50 h−1. The reaction effluents were passed through a sodium hydroxide solution to neutralize the remained HCl, following which they were tested using the Shimadzu on-line GC-2014C instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector. The conversion of acetylene and the selectivity to VCM were calculated according to previously reported equations [6]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of N@CBC-x Influence factors, including the molar ratio of formaldehyde (FE) to melamine, the content of PVA, the mass ratio of AC to melamine and the calcination temperature of the precursors, were investigated to optimize the preparation conditions of N@CBC-FE. Fig. 1 a displays the performance of the N@CBC-FE sample prepared with different molar ratios of FE/melamine. Rising the percentage of FE, the conversion of acetylene increases, and reaches the maximum conversion value of 42 % as the molar ratio of FE/melamine equals six. Subsequently, the activity begins to decrease as the FE/melamine ratio increases further. Previously, Duan and coworkers proposed that one melamine molecule could react with six FE molecules [63]. The FE/melamine ratio can modulate the degree of polymerization of MF resin, and then adjust the priority of adsorption of reactants over the as-synthesized N@CBC-FE catalyst. As shown in Fig. S1, the samples prepared with a relatively high ratio of FE/melamine ratio adsorb and activate HCl gas and inhibit the adsorption of C2H2. Based on the optimal FE/melamine, as depicted in Fig. 1b, high activity is achieved with the content of PVA ranging from 0.1 to 1 wt.%. When the content of PVA increases from 1 to 2 wt.%, the solution viscosity increases, resulting in large diffusion resistance. The optimal amount of PVA is 1 wt.%. It is distinctly important to control the concentration of the polymer and solution viscosity to obtain a desirable ingredient. At low PVA content, the viscosity of the solution reduces, hile at high PVA content the viscosity of solution increases so as to inhibit the diffusion into the pore structure [61,63–65]. With the addition of PVA, a cross-linking 3D branching N-containing carbon network could be constructed [66]. The mass ratio of AC/melamine is also optimized, as shown in Fig. 1c, with the increase in the mass of melamine, keeping the amount of carbon constant, the conversion of acetylene increases promptly and then reaches the maximum conversion of 59 % at the AC/melamine mass ratio of two. The activity is maintained stable as the ratio continuously increases to four. Finally, N@CBC-FE catalysts were produced under different calcination temperatures, maintaining the above optimal conditions, i.e., FE/melamine = 6 (mol/mol), PVA/MF =1 wt.% and AC/melamine = 2 (mass ratio). It can be seen that the conversion of acetylene increases when the calcination temperature is in the range of 500–700 °C, the optimal calcination temperature is 700 °C, as shown in Fig. 1 d. The activity decreases greatly as the temperature increases from 800 to 1000 °C, which is attributed to the decomposition of N-containing species at much high temperature. Based on the above optimal parameters for the FE-assisted N@CBC-FE production, the other two catalysts of N@CBC-EL and N@CBC-GL were prepared for acetylene hydrochlorination under the same conditions (220 °C and 180 h−1). As shown in Fig. 2 a and b, the N@CBC-FE catalyst shows the highest acetylene conversion of 60 %, while the N@CBC-EL and N@CBC-GL catalysts show relatively lower activities withconversions of 54 % and 55 %, respectively. For comparison, a catalyst was also synthesized via the mechanical mixing of melamine and CBC, followed by calcining at 700 °C. The obtained catalyst was evaluated for acetylene hydrochlorination, exhibiting a lower acetylene conversion of 49 % at the reaction time of 10 h, which was slightly higher than that of the original CBC. Therefore, it is critical to select a proper solvent to facilitate the preparation of N-doped samples from melamine. Furthermore, the catalytic stability of N@CBC-FE was evaluated at a GHSV (C2H2) of 50 h−1, which is commonly applied in the industrial production. Fig. 2 c and d show the performance of N@CBC-FE against the pristine CBC catalyst. The acetylene conversion of N@CBC-FE reaches a maximum of 75 % in the 120 h test. Meanwhile, its selectivity to VCM is still close to 100 % after 120 h, showing high activity and stability for the hydrochlorination of acetylene. These results indicate that the performance of the N@CBC-x catalysts is greatly associated with the solvent species that make melamine dissolved very well. Therefore, a series of characterizations were conducted to disclose the reasons that results in the superior activity of the N@CBC-x catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. 3.2 Interaction between the solvents and the structure of the prepared N@CBC-x catalysts 3.2.1 The textural structure of N@CBC-x N2 sorption isotherms were measured to analyze the texture property of the catalyst samples including N@CBC-FE, N@CBC-EL and N@CBC-GL. As shown in Fig. 3 a, all the samples presented the typical Type-I isotherm curves at low relative pressure (P/Po ＜ 0.1), corresponding to the microporous structure of the materials. Meanwhile, a tiny hysteresis loop appeared at the P/Po range of 0.5−0.9, which is related to the capillary condensation occurring in the mesopores. Moreover, compared to that of the original CBC, the nitrogen uptake of all the doped samples decreased greatly, indicating that the doping atoms entered the framework of the AC and occupied the space of the partial pores. Notably, the steep increase in the nitrogen uptake at high P/Po values (＞ 0.9) of N@CBC-FE indicates the development of secondary pores in the N@CBC-FE catalyst. To further investigate the effect of the pore size on the doped samples, the pore size distribution of the catalysts is depicted in Fig. 3 (b–d). In Fig. 3b, it can be observed that the N@CBC-x samples possess several micropores with peaks located at 0.55 ± 0.05 nm based on the HK method, which are approximate to those of the CBC. Meanwhile, Fig. 3 c and d show the mesopore size distribution according to the BJH model. Compared to the pristine CBC, the distributions of the mesopores of all the N@CBC-x samples are enhanced, particularly, the percentage of pores with sizes between 2 and 4 nm in the N@CBC-FE sample is quite higher than those in the other two N-doped samples. This indicates that the FE-assisted N@CBC-FE sample has abundant mesopores, which can be attributed to the decomposition of melamine and other organics at high temperature, as reported in the literature [67]. Previously, our group found that the high catalytic activity was probably associated with the hierarchical pore structure, including both micro-and mesopores, in the carbon supports. On the one hand, mesopores are favorable for the diffusion of reactants; on the other hand, the existence of a mesoporous structure could accelerate the desorption of VCM and retard the coking process [68]. The textural parameters of all the samples are also listed in Table S3. The surface area and pore volume of all the doped samples are lower than those of the CBC, indicating that the heteroatoms were successfully doped. Meanwhile, the high temperature during the doping process results in structural collapse or pore blockage by surface functional groups [67]. The mean pore size of N@CBC-x increases from 1.6 to 2.2 nm. This is caused by the ammonia generated from the decomposition of melamine, which plays an important role in the etching process [69]. 3.2.2 The surface defect of N@CBC-x In Fig. 4 , the Raman spectra of the four samples show the characteristic D band (1330 cm−1) and G band (1600 cm−1) peaks. The D band represents the disorder-defect degree in the carbon structure, while the G band is indicative of the graphitization degree of the sp2 carbon atoms in the carbon framework. The ratio of the intensities for the two peaks (ID/IG) is considered as a measure of the disorder degree associated with the carbon structure. With different solvent-doped samples, the intensities of the D band and G band increase in the order of ethanol ＜ glycol ＜ formaldehyde, indicating the enrichment of defects due to the transformation from the amorphous phase to graphite during the preparation process [70]. Meanwhile, the ID/IG ratio of the integral areas of the N-doped samples increases from 2.28 for CBC to 2.55 for N@CBC-FE. The N@CBC-FE catalyst has the highest ID/IG ratio among the three N-doped samples, indicating that it has the highest density of surface defects, and also implying thatit possesses the highest number of heteroatoms [71]. As is well known, defect sites on catalysts are regarded as adsorption sites and active sites, which improve the catalytic activity [72,73]. 3.2.3 The surface functional groups of N@CBC-x Fig. 5 shows the FTIR spectra of these catalysts. The peaks at 3423 cm−1, related to the amino (-NH2) and imino (-NH-) stretching groups, overlap with that corresponding to the stretching vibration of the hydroxyl groups (−OH) [58]. In contrast, the characteristic peaks of the 1, 3, 5-s-triazine ring located at 1542 and 1458 cm−1 are more pronounced for the N-doped samples than for the CBC, as shown in Fig. 5 b [63]. The above results confirm that the melamine-derived doping introduced the CN cross-linked network, which was ascribed to the 1, 3, 5-s-triazine ring. 3.2.4 The surface composition of N@CBC-x To investigate the effects of the different solvents on the preparation process, all the samples were subjected to XPS analysis to ascertain the surface composition and chemical states of the elements. In addition, the bulk elemental compositions of C, N and O were analyzed via elemental analysis. Table 1 lists the bulk and surface elemental compositions of all the catalysts. Compared to those of the pristine CBC, the C content decreases after doping, and the N content increases gradually. Among all the N-doped samples, N@CBC-FE has the highest amount of N and O. The surface element contents of CBC, N@CBC-EL, N@CBC-GL and N@CBC-FE catalysts are also listed in Table 1 (last three columns). The CBC exhibits an N atomic percentage of 1.74 at%, the percentages for N@CBC-EL, N@CBC-GL and N@CBC-FE are 4.1 at%, 4.07 at% and 4.81 at%, respectively. Correspondingly, the carbon content in N@CBC-x is lower than that in the pristine CBC. Therefore, it can be confirmed that N was successfully doped into the AC framework. In addition, the content of O in N@CBC-FE is 10 at%, which is the highest among the doped samples, due to the interaction of FE with melamine during the preparation process. To highlight the effect of solvents on the N-doping configurations in the matrix of CBC, Fig. 6 (a–d) depict the high-resolution spectra of N1s and O1s and the corresponding deconvolution profiles of CBC, N@CBC-EL, N@CBC-GL and N@CBC-FE. As shown in Fig. 6a, the peaks at 398.5 ± 0.1, 399.8 ± 0.2 and 401 ± 0.1 eV, which appeared simultaneously, are assigned to pyridinic-N ( N1 ), pyrrolic-N ( N2 ) and graphitic-N ( N3 ) species, respectively [74]. No N species is observed in CBC, while all the N@CBC-x catalysts consist of three N species. Fig. 6 b presents the percentages of the three different N species in the N-doped samples. The shift of the different chemical states of N does not vary with the different solvents; however, their relative intensity changes. The N1 and N3 contents increase gradually, while the N2 content decreases in the order of N@CBC-EL ＞ N@CBC-GL ＞ N@CBC-FE. To further investigate the influences of oxygen on the distribution of the N species in the N@CBC-x catalysts, the atomic percentages of each O species were also calculated based on their deconvolution profiles in Fig. 6 c. Three different O1s chemical shifts (named as O1 , O2 and O3 ) are assigned in all the samples. The components of O1 (531.3 ± 0.1 eV), O2 (532.1 ± 0.1 eV) and O3 (533.2 ± 0.1 eV) correspond to carbonyl, the CO bond in ether or alcohol and the single CO bond in ester or carboxyl group, respectively [74]. As shown in Fig. 6d, the relative content of the O1 component gradually increases as the contents of the O2 and O3 components decrease from CBC to N@CBC-FE. Correspondingly, the increase in the number of carbonyl groups could be attributed to the participation of FE in the synthesis of the N@CBC-FE catalyst. The carbonyl groups favor the acetylene hydrochlorination, and the result of the activity test is in accordance with the reported investigation results of previous surface carbonyl groups [75–77]. Meanwhile, the heteroatom dopants create bonds with the carbon after breaking the sp2 CC bonds during the doping process. Therefore, we investigate the change in the C1s spectra to confirm the doping process. The C1s spectra could be decomposed into three bonding species, C1 (sp2 CC bond in the graphite plane, 284.8 eV), C2 (CO bond in hydroxyl/ether or CN in the pyridine ring or amine, 285.6 ± 0.1 eV) and C3 (CO in the carboxyl/ester bond or CN in the amide bond, 289.6 ± 0.2 eV), as shown in Fig. S4 in Supporting Material [74,78]. As can be observed in Table S4, upon doping, the percentage of C1 decreases from 63.5 at% for CBC to 58.6 at% for N@CBC-FE. Meanwhile, the content of the C2 component derived from the dopant increases. In particular, the increase in the intensity of C2 in N@CBC-FE is notable, indicating that the catalyst possesses the largest amount of heteroatoms bonded with carbon atoms during doping. 3.2.5 The adsorption capacity of N@CBC-x TPD analysis is effective for determining the adsorption capacity of the catalysts for the reactants and products. Fig. 7 (a–c) show the HCl-TPD, VCM-TPD and C2H2-TPD profiles of the three samples of N@CBC-x prepared using ethanol, glycol and formaldehyde as the solvents, respectively. In Fig. 7a, an improvement in the adsorption capacity of HCl for all the N-doped samples is observed. Meanwhile, the desorption temperature of the N-doped samples shifts to a higher value (∼ 220 °C), indicating that the N-doping promotes the interaction between HCl and the N@CBC-x catalysts [19,25,79]. In addition, the N@CBC-FE catalyst displays the highest HCl adsorption capacity compared to those of other samples, as shown in Fig. 7 d. Meanwhile, the desorption peak temperature of N@CBC-FE is 222.1 °C, which reflects the strong interaction [39]. In contrast, Fig. 7 b shows the desorption of VCM on the N-doped samples. The peak area for all the N-doped samples is smaller than that for the pristine CBC. Compared to other N-doped samples, the N@CBC-FE sample has a similar VCM desorption temperature and peak area, as shown in Fig. 7 d. This indicates the FE-assisted N@CBC-FE process inhibits the desorption of VCM, which has been reported in previous literatures [23,80]. As shown in Fig. 7c, the desorption of C2H2 covers a temperature range of 100−300 °C, and the desorption temperature of the N-doped samples for C2H2 exhibits the following trend: CBC > N@CBC-EL > N@CBC-GL > N@CBC-FE. The N@CBC-FE sample displays the lowest C2H2 desorption temperature compared to those of the other samples, as shown in Fig. 7d, indicating that the C2H2 gas desorbs from the N-doped sample due to the medium-strong interaction, which is beneficial for the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. From the C2H2 desorption peak area in Fig. 7d, the acetylene desorption follows the sequence: N@CBC-FE > N@CBC-GL > N@CBC-EL > CBC, which is consistent with their activities in the hydrochlorination of acetylene. Arrigo and coworkers proposed that N-doping could tune the acidic and basic sites and change the electronic properties of CNFs [81]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the adsorption capacity of the N-doped ACs varies with different solvents. 3.2.6 Coke deposition of N@CBC-x The deactivation of NCM for acetylene hydrochlorination has been attributed to coking, which gives rise to the formation of carbonaceous deposits that cover the catalyst surface. The coking on the surface of the spent catalysts can be calculated via thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) technology. Generally, the mass loss comes from the oxidation of the sample itself and the burning of the coking on the surface of spent samples. To keep the same basis for the percentage when comparing the fresh and spent samples heated in the air atmosphere, the mass loss before 100 °C of all the samples is attributed to the desorption of water from the catalyst surface. The mass loss in the temperature range of 100−450 °C is corresponding to the coking deposition on the catalyst surface during acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, and the rapid loss after 450 °C is accountable for the burning of activated carbon [20,23,25,82]. The coking of CBC and N@CBC-FE catalysts after reaction over 60 h is depicted in Fig. 8 . The coking percentages of CBC and N@CBC-FE is 5.25 % and 2.49 %, respectively. The result indicates that the N-doping could indeed alleviate the deactivation rate, which is attributed to the reaction between the N species and surface acidic sites. Meantime, in-situ Py-IR experiment for the N@CBC-FE and CBC samples were conducted by using Py as a useful probe molecule to investigate the possible Brønsted and Lewis acid centers of solid catalysts. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the peaks centered at 1446 cm−1 and 1596 cm−1 are assigned to the Lewis acidic sites. The peaks at 1490 cm−1 and 1537 cm−1 are attributed to the Brønsted acidic sites [68,83,84]. It can be seen in Fig. 9 a that the doping process makes the Brønsted acidic sites disappeared and decreases the intensity of Lewis acidic sites. Furthermore, NH3-TPD experiments were conducted to investigate the changes of surface acidic sites before and after doping. Comparing the total NH3 desorption amount, the signal of N@CBC-FE is extremely lower than that of CBC, suggesting that the doping process indeed reduces the surface acidic sites, especially the Brønsted acidic sites, which could alleviate the coking of the catalysts for the hydrochlorination of acetylene. These characterizations suggest that the best catalytic activity with the highest N content, comparing with other N-doped samples. It is interesting to figure out the possible reasons for this phenomenon. Then we analyzed and correlated the structures and the activity with the corresponding properties of N-doped catalysts. 3.3 Relationships between the structure and catalytic activity of the prepared N@CBC-x catalysts 3.3.1 Relationship between the defect sites and the activity of N@CBC-x Generally, the defects sites caused by heteroatom doping are regarded as possible actives sites, which activate the reactants to promote catalytic reactions [48]. It is necessary to investigate the relationship between the activity and the defect sites. As presented in Fig. 10 a, a good linear fitting between the activity of N@CBC-x and the corresponding ID/IG ratio is deduced. Furthermore, a linear fitting between the ID/IG ratio and the total N content in the N@CBC-x catalysts is derived, as shown in Fig. 10 b. With the increase in the N amount, the number of defect sites in the N-doped samples increases gradually, which is consistent with the literatures reports, that doping heteroatoms into carbon matrix leads to an increase in randomness [70,85]. 3.3.2 Relationship between the nitrogen species and the activity of N@CBC-x N-doping improves the activity of AC-based catalysts significantly by altering the local structure of the carbon atoms. Yao and Dai proposed that the doped N could be removed to produce new defect sites via calcination at high temperatures [49,73], an experimental to remove the doped N was conducted via calcination at 1000 °C in N2 atmosphere. Fig. 11 shows the changes in the activity of the N-doped catalysts with and without calcination. As shown in Fig. 11a, the conversions of N@CBC-EL-1000, N@CBC-GL-1000 and N@CBC-FE-1000 after calcination decreased significantly. Evidently, the doping is responsible for the improvement of the catalytic activity. This result is consistent with previous reports [67,86]. Bao and coworkers proposed that for an N-doped AC-based catalyst, a high activity corresponds to high N content and high dispersion [18]. The origin of the catalytic activity in N-doped carbon catalysts prepared with different solvents is affiliated to the interaction of different species. For example, the surface N species and defective sites in the N@CBC-x catalysts may also contribute to their catalytic activities. As is well-known, the pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N and quaternary-N type have been debated as the possible active sites for the reaction. Notably, an increase in the N content is accompanied by in the amounts of N1 and N3 . Thus, we examined the relationship between the activity and the amount of specific N species in the N@CBC-x samples. As shown in Fig. 12 (a–c), with increasing levels of N1 and N3 , the activities of all the N@CBC-x catalysts improve correspondingly. No clear relationship is observed between the single specific N species and the total surface N species, as well as the activity of the N-doped catalysts. However, when correlating the activity with the sum of the surface N and defect sites (indicated by the value of ID/IG, quantitatively), a good linear fitting line is obtained, as depicted in Fig. 12 d. This strongly suggests that N-related species and defect sites are the possible active sites of N@CBC-x, which is consistent with the results of Zhao and coworkers [57,87]. Deng and coworkers also emphasized that introducing graphitic-N species into the carbon network increased the electron density of states near the Fermi level [88]. Based on the above discussion, it is concluded that the performances of the N@CBC-x catalysts are functions of the surface defect sites and the different N species. 3.3.3 Relationship between the oxygen species and the activity of N@CBC-x The simultaneous appearance of strong N1s and O1s peaks in the XPS spectrum, as well as bulk element analysis, confirms the successful introduction of N species along with oxygen species into N@CBC-FE. It is reasonable that the surface N and oxygen contents are much lower than those detected by elemental analysis because of the XPS probing depth limitation. Strangely, the high level of carbonyl species ( O1 species) on the surface of the N@CBC-FE catalyst originates from the precursor solvent, i.e., formaldehyde. To highlight the role of oxygen in the carbon matrix, the deconvoluted profile of O1s is examined to estimate the contribution of different oxygen species. Therein, we find that the percentage of O1 in the N@CBC-x catalysts increases, particularly, N@CBC-FE has the largest content of O1 , indicating that more carbonyl groups are created during the doping process, which is attributed to the FE solvent. Generally, the conjugation of carbonyl groups with an aromatic system could enhance the electron cloud density [76,89]. Furthermore, the results from the C1s spectrum (see Fig. S4 in Supporting Material) suggest that ∼ 25.2 at% C atom ( C2 , CO bond in hydroxyl/ether or CN in pyridine ring or amine, 285.6 ± 0.1 eV) is directly bonded to O and/or N atoms. The enrichment of O and N functional groups in the N@CBC-FE catalyst can endow it with enhanced activity. Additionally, Bandosz and coworkers found that the introduction of oxygen increased the amount of N incorporated into the carbon matrix when they modified carbon with different N-containing precursors [75]. Li and coworkers also proposed that the introduction of O species could modulate the content and distribution of N species during the synthesis of NCM [71]. Therefore, it is concluded that the introduction of oxygen species could modulate the content and distribution of N species in N@CBC-FE, which is related to the reaction between melamine and the oxygen-containing functional groups [90]. Furthermore, the attenuated total reflectance infrared (ATR-IR) spectra of the MFP resin calcinated at different temperatures were recorded to investigate the variation of the surface functional groups during the preparation of N@CBC-FE. As illustrated in Fig. 13 , the peaks situated at 3733 and 3726 cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibration of NH in amino (-NH2) and imino- (-NH-) [63]. The peaks of methylene (−CH2-) are situated at 2930 and 2852 cm−1. The band at 1562 cm−1 is assigned to the 1, 3, 5-s-triazine ring. The twisting vibration mode of the NH bond is indicated at 1615 and 1654 cm−1 [61,65]. In Fig. 13 b and c, it is observed that all the characteristic peaks of precursors change with the increasing calcination temperature from 90 to 700 °C. At temperature lower than 220 °C, the characteristic peak of FE is pronounced at 1518 cm−1. However, the band disappears gradually as the calcination temperature increases up to 700 °C. It is well known that FE can interact with melamine at a high temperature. Meanwhile, there appear a series of new characteristic peaks of the MF polymer, including triazine rings, methylene, amino and imino groups. The corresponding peak intensity variations at different temperatures reflect the degree of polymerization, confirming the reaction between the amine groups and formaldehyde. Thus, the FE facilitates the dispersion of melamine in the solution, while participating in the formation of the polymeric network coating via the reaction with PVA and melamine. It is such polymeric network coating process that results in effective active sites, anchoring on the surface of the CBC after calcination. 4 Conclusions N-doped AC-based catalysts were synthesized via a melamine/formaldehyde/PVA coating-pyrolysis method, and the effects of the preparation parameters, including the molar ratio of formaldehyde to melamine, content of PVA, mass ratio of AC to melamine and the calcination temperature of the precursors were investigated in details. An acetylene conversion as high as 75 % was achieved over the N@CBC-FE catalyst under the condition of 220 °C and 50 h−1 GHSV(C2H2) in 120 h. To disclose the structure-activity relationship, a series of characterizations was performed, including texture, surface graphitization, surface functional group, surface adsorption property and surface N/O species distribution analyses, for the as-synopsized samples. The results revealed that the N@CBC-FE catalyst exhibited the best activity, which was attributed to the incorporation of N and defect sites in it. Meanwhile, the enrichment of mesopores in the N@CBC-FE catalyst also offered channels for the reactant and product transport and diffusion. Furthermore, the surface N and defect sites are the critical factors contributing to the high catalytic activity. This work is expected to offer new insights for the synthesis of N-doped AC-based catalysts. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yawen Liu: Investigation, Writing - original draft. coredata.dc:description: N-doped carbon-based materials have been regarded as promising alternative metal-free catalysts for the production of vinyl chloride monomer. In this work, N-doped carbon-based catalysts were synthesized via a melamine/formaldehyde/ polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) coating-pyrolysis method, and the performances of the resultant catalysts (N@CBC-FE) were investigated and compared with those of the control samples. The optimal N@CBC-FE catalyst presented the highest acetylene conversion of 75 % at 220 °C and an acetylene gas hourly space velocity of 50 h−1 in 120 h. N2 sorption, Raman spectroscopy, attenuated total Reflectance-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and temperature-programmed desorption analysis results revealed that the excellent performance of N@CBC-FE was mainly attributed to the unique nitrogen intercalation pathway generated by the polymeric network coating, which was produced by the reactions among formaldehyde, PVA and melamine. Moreover, the abundant mesopores of N@CBC-FE facilitated the transfer of the reactants and retarded the deactivation process. This work is expected to provide new insights for the preparation of N-doped activated carbon-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Solvent-assisted synthesis of N-doped activated carbon-based catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination
